reasoning: The critique targets a relatively minor evidential move in section 2.3.2 (using present-day billionaire philanthropy to weakly suggest that vastly increased wealth may not raise proportional altruistic spending much). Even if this point were removed, the essay’s broader case against WAM-convergence and its emphasis on trade/compromise and threats largely stands, so centrality is low. Within that sub-argument, the critique substantially weakens the probative force of the billionaire-donation data (confounding factors; very long extrapolation to post-AGI choice architectures), though it doesn’t fully refute the essay’s broader claim that wealth needn’t imply altruism, especially because the essay already frames the evidence as weak and allows for other slowly-diminishing preferences. The critique is mostly correct and clearly stated, with little fluff and a single focused issue.
title: Current billionaire philanthropy poorly predicts post-AGI altruistic resource allocation
